questiontext.text:
We can approximate a 95% confidence interval (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population mean lands inside these intervals) by using x‾±2sn\bar{x}\pm \frac{2 s}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=x‾−2sn\text{lower boundary} = \bar{x}-\frac{2s}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=x‾+2sn\text{upper boundary} = \bar{x}+\frac{2s}{\sqrt{n}} where x‾\bar{x} is the sample mean, ss is the sample standard deviation, and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample mean is called the margin of error. margin of error=2sn\text{margin of error} = \frac{2s}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know ss will be approximately 0.81, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.0053, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:
Do some algebra. ME=2snME = \frac{2s}{\sqrt{n}} Multiply both sides by n\sqrt{n}. MEn=2sME\sqrt{n} = 2s Divide both sides by MEME. n=2sME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2s}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2sME)2n = \left(\frac{2s}{ME}\right)^2 Plug in numbers. n=((2)(0.81)0.0053)2n = \left(\frac{(2)(0.81)}{0.0053}\right)^2 Evaluate. n=93428n = 93428

The tolerance is ±1000\pm 1000, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=93000n=93000.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know p̂\hat{p} will be approximately 0.56, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.0032, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:
Do some algebra. ME=2p̂(1−p̂)nME = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} Multiply both sides by n\sqrt{n}. MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.56)(0.44)0.00322n = \frac{4(0.56)(0.44)}{0.0032^2} Evaluate. n=96250n = 96250

The tolerance is ±1000\pm 1000, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=96000n=96000.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.6)(0.4)0.00382n = \frac{4(0.6)(0.4)}{0.0038^2} Evaluate. n=66482n = 66482

The tolerance is ±1000\pm 1000, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=66000n=66000.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know p̂\hat{p} will be approximately 0.63, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.065, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:
Do some algebra. ME=2p̂(1−p̂)nME = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} Multiply both sides by n\sqrt{n}. MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.63)(0.37)0.0652n = \frac{4(0.63)(0.37)}{0.065^2} Evaluate. n=221n = 221

The tolerance is ±10\pm 10, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=220n=220.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know p̂\hat{p} will be approximately 0.7, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.042, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:
Do some algebra. ME=2p̂(1−p̂)nME = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} Multiply both sides by n\sqrt{n}. MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.7)(0.3)0.0422n = \frac{4(0.7)(0.3)}{0.042^2} Evaluate. n=476n = 476

The tolerance is ±10\pm 10, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=480n=480.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

The tolerance is ±100\pm 100, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=5900n=5900.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.67)(0.33)0.00532n = \frac{4(0.67)(0.33)}{0.0053^2} Evaluate. n=31485n = 31485

The tolerance is ±1000\pm 1000, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=31000n=31000.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know p̂\hat{p} will be approximately 0.1, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.0028, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:

MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.1)(0.9)0.00282n = \frac{4(0.1)(0.9)}{0.0028^2} Evaluate. n=45918n = 45918

The tolerance is ±1000\pm 1000, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=46000n=46000.

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently the true population proportion lands inside these intervals) by using p̂±2p̂(1−p̂)n\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}. lower boundary=p̂−2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} upper boundary=p̂+2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} where p̂\hat{p} is the sample proportion and nn is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proprotion is called the margin of error. margin of error=2p̂(1−p̂)n\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}

If we know p̂\hat{p} will be approximately 0.52, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.032, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.

generalfeedback.text:
Do some algebra. ME=2p̂(1−p̂)nME = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}} Multiply both sides by n\sqrt{n}. MEn=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = 2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})} Divide both sides by MEME. n=2p̂(1−p̂)ME\sqrt{n} = \frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME} Square both sides. n=(2p̂(1−p̂)ME)2n = \left(\frac{2\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{ME}\right)^2 Simplify. n=4p̂(1−p̂)ME2n = \frac{4\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{ME^2}

Plug in numbers. n=4(0.52)(0.48)0.0322n = \frac{4(0.52)(0.48)}{0.032^2} Evaluate. n=975n = 975

The tolerance is ±10\pm 10, so you can round to 2 significant digits, giving n=980n=980.
